text: on the front line near Samarra between
Baghdad and Musa these forces battling
against the so-called Islamic state are
not died at the army but a volunteer
Shia militia called the Salaam Brigade
Shia militias are fighting really hard
to stop the advance of the so-called
Islamic state militants who are just
behind this hill Shia militias are an
effective force on the ground but the
role in this conflict is pretty
controversial given the fears of
sectarian tensions in Iraq for nearly
four months now
the Salaam Brigade has been stationed
here there are many other Shia volunteer
groups too and their reputations vary
some have been accused of human rights
abuses they are backed by and relied
upon by the new shia-led government
following the retreat of the Regular
Army from large areas of the country
other religious groups particularly
Sunnis fear persecution and worry these
Shia weapons might be turned against
them when the fight against Islamic
state is over a Salaam Brigade field
commander who asked us not to reveal his
identity told us such fears were
unfounded
Ikeda Schumacher mahalo Metacomet we are
filling in the gaps and the battlefield
the Iraqi army was weakened by the
American invasion and needs our help
we have been defending areas where Sunni
Shia Yazidis and Christians live and we
protect them all
the influence of the Shia militias is
also visible on the streets of Baghdad
their message adorns billboards across
the capital non Shia Iraqis are
concerned Levu daniel has ursula via the
done' weapons should be kept in the
hands of the Regular Army and the police
these volunteers have a short-term role
in defeating Isis but should be
disbanded after the world the Iraqi
government says it plans to merge the
Shia militias into the Regular Army but
as yet they have not put those plans
into effect
Serena Beale BBC News Samara
